title: How I Learned to Embrace My Scars to Educate Others

content: The keloid scar left behind by my chemo port has become one of the most prominent conversation starters in my life post-treatment. Outside of this permanent mark below my collarbone, there’s no blatantly visible evidence of my history of breast cancer. When my scar is in plain sight, it always prompts questions like, “What’s that from?” or “What’d you do there?”
Five months of chemotherapy is what I did there.

Initially, when I started getting these questions, I wasn’t sure how much I should share. I didn’t want to overwhelm anyone with my entire story. People’s curiosity never offended me because I trusted that it was genuine. Even so, it didn’t make it any less triggering to unintentionally be reminded of everything I’ve endured.

The first few times people noticed my scar, I’d give them a vague answer and try to change the subject as quickly as possible. However, the more people kept asking about it -- whether it was on dates, hanging out with new groups of people, at parties, etc. -- the more I realized that this question was never going away. So instead of holding back my truth out of the fear of it being too much, I began allowing myself to freely and honestly embrace it.

content: One of the most vulnerable moments of my life was when I shared my story with a group of co-workers in college. It was a few weeks after my double-mastectomy surgery, and we were starting our staff meeting with an icebreaker. Each person drew a different question from a hat, mine being, “What is something we probably don’t know about you?” I immediately felt as if that question was somehow purposely placed in the hat for me.

I listened to everyone else answer their questions while mentally debating whether to shift the lighthearted dynamic into a much heavier one. I almost persuaded myself into using my go-to answer -- I’m scared of dogs -- but something inside of me urged me to speak bravely. With tears streaming down my face, I shared everything I’d been going through the past several months.

content: I’ll never forget the faces of shock, claps of praise, and warm embraces I received from my team that day. Many questions followed and I answered all of them without hesitation. I left that meeting feeling more empowered than ever before, and since then, I’ve become more confident in sharing my story.

content: Now when people notice my scar, I don’t hesitate to proudly share that I’m a breast cancer survivor. I’ve gotten used to people’s reactions usually being somewhere in between completely shocked and incredibly confused. I use these moments as an opportunity to educate those around me on breast health and encourage them to be aware of what’s going on in their bodies.

While my scar may appear as an outward blemish, it has internally become one of my most treasured features. I’m thankful for each conversation that has started because of it, and I look forward to those yet to occur.
